body:
Thanks for the quick reply. I'm still confused. The [Go language spec suggests](https://golang.org/ref/spec#Switch_statements) in its example that such construct is possible:

```go
switch i := x.(type) {
case bool, string:
	printString("type is bool or string")
default:
	printString("don't know the type")
}
```

Here we see the same `case` statement for both `bool` and `string`. Why wouldn't it be possible for two different types that implement the same interface, like in my example above?
